2.title: Simplr Router
2.headline: Small
2.body: No dependencies and a small codebase means less breaking parts. 0 dependencies means that what you see is what you get.

3.title: Simplr Router
3.headline: Easy to transition into
3.body: Works by utilizing the native API's used for navigation and therefore doesn't require any extra steps compared to your every day MPA.

4.title: Simplr Router
4.headline: Web Component focused
4.body: Built with web components, for web components. Simplr Router was designed from the get go to be used in web component applications.

5.title: Simplr Router
5.headline: Customizable
5.body: Even though there's no configuration necessary to get started, the router ships with a lot of customizability to fit your needs.

6.title: Simplr Router
6.headline: Performant
6.body: Allowing for lazy loading and creating dynamic routes, Simplr Router is a great library for projects of all sizes.

40.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
40.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
40.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

56.title: Recipes: Error pages
56.headline: Recipes: Error pages
56.body:
Simplr router supports 2 kinds of error pages by default: 

Not found -page 
Forbidden/Unauthorized -page 
 
These have special routings set up for them inside the router, and are programmed into the router. 
In action this means that if a not found -page is set in the routes, it will be displayed by the router in a case
where the route provided by the user is not found on the application.

80.title: Getting started: Using a starter
80.headline: Initial setup
80.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

81.title: Getting started: Using a starter
81.headline: Installing the router
81.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

144.title: Customizing: Middleware
144.headline: Customizing: Middleware
144.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows: 








Method Type Description

186.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
186.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
186.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

200.title: Customizing: Middleware
200.headline: Reactive events
200.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

201.title: Customizing: Middleware
201.headline: Overriding events
201.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

f.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
f.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
f.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

1y.title: Recipes: Guards
1y.headline: Recipes: Guards
1y.body:
Route guards can be used to prevent access to certain pages from users. 
Guards are a programmatic interface that allows you to create custom guard functions to check if the current user is authorized to
view a route.

8b.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
8b.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
8b.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

c0.title: Simplr Router
c0.headline: Why Simplr RouterQuick and simple
c0.body: Simple to get up and running. Basic setup in just a few lines of code.

c1.title: Simplr Router
c1.headline: Small
c1.body: No dependencies and a small codebase means less breaking parts. 0 dependencies means that what you see is what you get.

c2.title: Simplr Router
c2.headline: Easy to transition into
c2.body: Works by utilizing the native API's used for navigation and therefore doesn't require any extra steps compared to your every day MPA.

c3.title: Simplr Router
c3.headline: Web Component focused
c3.body: Built with web components, for web components. Simplr Router was designed from the get go to be used in web component applications.

c4.title: Simplr Router
c4.headline: Customizable
c4.body: Even though there's no configuration necessary to get started, the router ships with a lot of customizability to fit your needs.

c5.title: Simplr Router
c5.headline: Performant
c5.body: Allowing for lazy loading and creating dynamic routes, Simplr Router is a great library for projects of all sizes.

cb.title: Getting started: Using a starter
cb.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
cb.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

cc.title: Getting started: Using a starter
cc.headline: Initial setup
cc.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

cd.title: Getting started: Using a starter
cd.headline: Installing the router
cd.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

co.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
co.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
co.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

gn.title: Getting started: Using a starter
gn.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
gn.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

go.title: Getting started: Using a starter
go.headline: Initial setup
go.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

gp.title: Getting started: Using a starter
gp.headline: Installing the router
gp.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

h0.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
h0.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
h0.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

hd.title: Simplr Router
hd.headline: Why Simplr RouterQuick and simple
hd.body: Simple to get up and running. Basic setup in just a few lines of code.

he.title: Simplr Router
he.headline: Small
he.body: No dependencies and a small codebase means less breaking parts. 0 dependencies means that what you see is what you get.

hf.title: Simplr Router
hf.headline: Easy to transition into
hf.body: Works by utilizing the native API's used for navigation and therefore doesn't require any extra steps compared to your every day MPA.

hg.title: Simplr Router
hg.headline: Web Component focused
hg.body: Built with web components, for web components. Simplr Router was designed from the get go to be used in web component applications.

hh.title: Simplr Router
hh.headline: Customizable
hh.body: Even though there's no configuration necessary to get started, the router ships with a lot of customizability to fit your needs.

hi.title: Simplr Router
hi.headline: Performant
hi.body: Allowing for lazy loading and creating dynamic routes, Simplr Router is a great library for projects of all sizes.

ie.title: Recipes: Slots
ie.headline: Recipes: Slots
ie.body:
Simplr Router allows you to define slots to be appended to the view while the view is loaded to DOM. 
This allows creating views with dynamic slotted elements depending on the route the user accessed the view from.

lc.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
lc.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
lc.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter

m4.title: Getting started: Using a starter
m4.headline: Initial setup
m4.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

m5.title: Getting started: Using a starter
m5.headline: Installing the router
m5.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

qj.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

qk.title: Getting started: Using a starter
qk.headline: Initial setup
qk.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

ql.title: Getting started: Using a starter
ql.headline: Installing the router
ql.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

qw.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
qw.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
qw.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

v2.title: Getting started: Using a starter
v2.headline: Initial setup
v2.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

v3.title: Getting started: Using a starter
v3.headline: Installing the router
v3.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

ve.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
ve.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
ve.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

vs.headline: Small

vt.headline: Easy to transition into

vu.headline: Web Component focused

vw.title: Simplr Router
vw.headline: Performant
vw.body: Allowing for lazy loading and creating dynamic routes, Simplr Router is a great library for projects of all sizes.

10u.title: Getting started: Using a starter
10u.headline: Initial setup
10u.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

10v.title: Getting started: Using a starter
10v.headline: Installing the router
10v.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

12c.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
12c.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
12c.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

16u.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
16u.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
16u.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

17m.title: Customizing: Middleware
17m.headline: Customizing: Middleware
17m.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows: 















Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject  routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contains data about the route, if one was found.    
This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens. 
Another use-case could be for example Logging |

npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

1c9.title: Customizing: Middleware
1c9.headline: Customizing: Middleware
1c9.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows: 















Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject  routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contains data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example Logging      

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

1ci.title: Getting started: Using a starter
1ci.headline: Initial setup
1ci.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

1cj.title: Getting started: Using a starter
1cj.headline: Installing the router
1cj.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

1cu.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1cu.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1cu.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

1gy.title: Customizing: Middleware
1gy.headline: Customizing: Middleware
1gy.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows: 















Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject  routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics        

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1h6.title: Getting started: Using a starter
1h6.headline: Initial setup
1h6.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

1h7.title: Getting started: Using a starter
1h7.headline: Installing the router
1h7.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

1hi.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1hi.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1hi.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

1kg.title: Customizing: Middleware
1kg.headline: Customizing: Middleware
1kg.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows: 




















Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject  routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing  routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.

const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

1lm.title: Customizing: Middleware
1lm.headline: Customizing: Middleware
1lm.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows: 




















Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject  routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing  routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.      

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1p4.title: Customizing: Middleware
1p4.headline: Customizing: Middleware
1p4.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows: 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

1po.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1po.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1po.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

1qa.title: Customizing: Middleware
1qa.headline: Customizing: Middleware
1qa.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows: 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.      

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1tv.title: Customizing: Middleware
1tv.headline: Customizing: Middleware
1tv.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

1tw.title: Customizing: Middleware
1tw.headline: Reactive events
1tw.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

1tx.title: Customizing: Middleware
1tx.headline: Overriding events
1tx.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing       

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1uh.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1uh.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1uh.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

1v3.title: Customizing: Middleware
1v3.headline: Customizing: Middleware
1v3.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

1v4.title: Customizing: Middleware
1v4.headline: Reactive events
1v4.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

1v5.title: Customizing: Middleware
1v5.headline: Overriding events
1v5.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

1xl.headline: Overriding events
1xl.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation           

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?

1y5.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1y5.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1y5.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

1yq.title: Customizing: Middleware
1yq.headline: Customizing: Middleware
1yq.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

1yr.title: Customizing: Middleware
1yr.headline: Reactive events
1yr.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

1ys.title: Customizing: Middleware
1ys.headline: Overriding events
1ys.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

23p.title: Customizing: Middleware
23p.headline: Customizing: Middleware
23p.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

23q.title: Customizing: Middleware
23q.headline: Reactive events
23q.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

23r.title: Customizing: Middleware
23r.headline: Overriding events
23r.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

24c.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
24c.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
24c.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

28s.title: Customizing: Middleware
28s.headline: Customizing: Middleware
28s.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

28t.title: Customizing: Middleware
28t.headline: Reactive events
28t.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

28u.title: Customizing: Middleware
28u.headline: Overriding events
28u.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

29g.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
29g.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
29g.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

2ad.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
2ad.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
2ad.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes.

2ae.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
2ae.headline: Demo on using an outlet
2ae.body:
render() {}
      <main>
        <div class="logo"><img alt="open-wc logo" src=${logo} /></div>
        <simplr-router-outlet></simplr-router-outlet>
      </main>
      }

2cs.title: Customizing: Middleware
2cs.headline: Customizing: Middleware
2cs.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

2ct.title: Customizing: Middleware
2ct.headline: Reactive events
2ct.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

2cu.title: Customizing: Middleware
2cu.headline: Overriding events
2cu.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

2cv.headline: Using a middleware

2cz.title: Getting started: Using a starter
2cz.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
2cz.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

2d0.title: Getting started: Using a starter
2d0.headline: Initial setup
2d0.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

2d1.title: Getting started: Using a starter
2d1.headline: Installing the router
2d1.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

2da.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
2da.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
2da.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes.

2de.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
2de.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
2de.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

2e1.headline: Overriding events

These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. 2gc.headline: Why Simplr RouterQuick and simple
2gc.body: Simple to get up and running. Basic setup in just a few lines of code.

2gd.title: Simplr Router
2gd.headline: Small
2gd.body: No dependencies and a small codebase means less breaking parts. 0 dependencies means that what you see is what you get.

2ge.title: Simplr Router
2ge.headline: Easy to transition into
2ge.body: Works by utilizing the native API's used for navigation and therefore doesn't require any extra steps compared to your every day MPA.

2gf.title: Simplr Router
2gf.headline: Web Component focused
2gf.body: Built with web components, for web components. Simplr Router was designed from the get go to be used in web component applications.

2gg.title: Simplr Router
2gg.headline: Customizable
2gg.body: Even though there's no configuration necessary to get started, the router ships with a lot of customizability to fit your needs.

2gh.title: Simplr Router
2gh.headline: Performant
2gh.body: Allowing for lazy loading and creating dynamic routes, Simplr Router is a great library for projects of all sizes.

2gl.title: Customizing: Middleware
2gl.headline: Customizing: Middleware
2gl.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

2gm.title: Customizing: Middleware
2gm.headline: Reactive events
2gm.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

2gn.title: Customizing: Middleware
2gn.headline: Overriding events
2gn.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

2gw.title: Getting started: Using a starter
2gw.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
2gw.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

2gx.title: Getting started: Using a starter
2gx.headline: Initial setup
2gx.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

2gy.title: Getting started: Using a starter
2gy.headline: Installing the router
2gy.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

2h7.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
2h7.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
2h7.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes.

2ha.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
2ha.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
2ha.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

2jt.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
2jt.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
2jt.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

2ju.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
2ju.headline: Using an outlet
2ju.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior.
